It sounds like a son who after loses his mother acts like its no big deal, and then later in life he realizes just how important she was to him. He tells the story out of order for dramatic effect so timeline-wise the story really starts with these lines:

âRebel, my new last name
Wild blood in my veins
Apron strings around my neck
The mark that still remainsâ

 âCutting the apron stringsâ is a saying which means going off and being physically and emotionally independent from your mum, so he may have initially perceived her as a limiting force when he says things like âapron strings around my neckâ. With this verse he communicates his need to rebel at that point in life and to reject domestic life which was the domain of his mother. He has âwild bloodâ in his veins and he wanted to get out and be independent. When he says âthe mark that still remainsâ it could mean a few things, either that up until this point he always remembered his mother in the negative light of someone he wanted to escape or alternatively it could mean that this negative relationship that he had with mother when she was dying has scarred him for life. 

He then goes on to say that he left home young and that might be wrong but he knows that leaving home after she died isnât the problem here, it was his relationship with her. I think he puts this line in there about leaving home to say that he was always going to leave and go do big things anyway, heâs not just leaving her specifically.

Iâll come to the chorus later, now we go back to the first verse where he is an adult looking back and he viewing his mother more fondly:

âMama, she has taught me well
Told me when I was young
"Son, your life's an open book
Don't close it 'fore it's done"

"The brightest flame burns quickest"
That's what I heard her say
A son's heart sowed to mother
But I must find my wayâ

Here it looks like heâs realized that she was wise in her own way and itâs only as an adult can he understand that wisdom. The âbrightest flameâ line is interesting because it shows that he sees that she really did understand him and his extreme creation/destruction tendencies. For those who were wondering there is a line in Blade Runner where they say that âa star that burns twice as bright burns twice as fastâ so the âbrightest flame burns quickestâ is a similar concept, ie being spent up by your lifestyle. Iâm not surprised to hear James use fire metaphors after his pyrotechnics accident!

Now the next verse:

âMama, now I'm coming home
I'm not all you wished of me
A mother's love for her son
Unspoken, help me be

Yeah, I took your love for granted
Not a thing you said to me
I need your arms to welcome me
But a cold stone's all I seeâ

So now heâs ready to come back to that relationship with his mum after all the growing that he has done away from her. Heâs a successful musician and he wants her to be proud but it sounds like he might not think that he was the best person. He wants her to help him and comfort him, heâs ready for that guidance and love again. However, the sorrow at the heart of the song is that she died. He wants her to hold him in her arms but all he has got to embrace is her tombstone.

Personally I see the verses as being there to tell the story and I see the chorus and bridge as direct expressions of this sorrow:

âLet my heart go
Let your son grow
Mama, let my heart go
Oh, let this heart be still

Let my heart go
Mama, let my heart go
You never let my heart go
So, let this heart be stillâ

These chorus lines are far more ambiguous than the verses, so they could mean a lot of things. The pain he feels is pretty clear, in light of the story in the verses I think heâs never been able to escape the pain of losing her, heâs never been able to move on from that pain or be free of that pain. His motherâs got his heart, ie he still feels extraordinary love for her and it pains him. So he seems to be asking to be free of that pain or at least to âlet this heart be stillâ, which might mean he wants peace from this emotional turmoil.  You could interpret it literally that he wanted her to let him go when he was a teenager but it doesnât really fit in with the rest of the emotion. And the bridge part:

âNever I ask of you
But never I gave
But you gave me your emptiness
I now take to my graveâ

âEmptinessâ is another ambiguous word, he could be saying a lot of things here. I think not having her has left an emptiness in his life, and that canât be filled. 

Itâs a pretty revealing song, we never really saw this side of James before Nothing Else Matters so its great that he started to become comfortable in expressing his deeper emotional stuff! Anyway this was my interpretation, itâs alarmingly long but it think the song has got a lot in it!

comment_44:
Mama she has taught me well
Told me when I was young
Son your life's an open book
Don't close it 'fore its done

The brightest flame burns quickest
That's what I heard her say
A son's heart's owed to mother
But I must find my way
------------------------------------

My Interpretation of what this song means is a bit complex, but they are of my own thoughts based on my experience and what this song means to me.

In the beginning it explains that his mother is teaching him that he has plenty of opportunity to make something of himself and he should shouldn't try so hard to grow up so fast. Her explaining "The brightest flame burns quickest" is her way of telling him if he tries to rush through life he will skip through childhood and never really enjoy his life. He needs to slow down and take his time, rather than rush through life and dim out.

Unfortunately he refuses to listen like many of us have done. We tried so hard to get out crap together and move on. We didn't want to live under a matriarch or someone else's rules so we just moved out without a plan. 

He is explaining that he needs to get out and figure it out himself.
-----------------------------------

Let my heart go
Let your son grow
Mama, let my heart go
Or let this heart be still
Yeah, still
--------------------------------

In this it is merely explaining that he is telling his mother to let him go, let him experience life, let him grow up the rest of the way on his own because he has big plans. He needs to get out.
-------------------------------------------------

Rebel, my new last name
Wild blood in my veins
Apron strings around my neck

The mark that still remains
Left home at an early age
Of what I heard was wrong
I never asked forgiveness
But what is said is done
------------------------------------------

When he first realized he was free he started doing all types of stuff a typical kid would do without supervision. He was trying to say that in the beginning it was touch and go, trying to find his place in the world... living life in the fast lane, his music career taking off and him and the band lived without any sense of responsibility. They drank and partied, went on tour, They were wild in the beginning. The band was also known as Alcoholica because of the wild parties they had, as well as the drinking... But during this he when the party stopped and he was alone he reflected on the how he grew up. He kind of missed the domestic life and he misses it by saying the mark that still remains from having Apron Strings around his neck.

He also reflects on how he left home, it seems like there were some words between him and his mother and he left on bad terms. He may have explained how he left to one of the band members and they told him he screwed up. His guilt is thick in the last lines... I never asked forgiveness, but what I said is done. He may have had the last words, and those words broke his mothers heart, and he can't take it back. He is too proud to ever admit to his mother that he was wrong, and he was sorry.
----------------------------------------

Never I ask of you
But never I gave
But you gave me your emptiness that I'll take to my grave
-------------------------------------------

He has even more guilt in these lyrics because he never asked for forgiveness... and he will also never give her forgiveness in return.
The animosity between the two still remains, and he will take that empty feeling, and sadness with him to his grave
---------------------------------------------

Mama, now I'm coming home
I'm not all you wished of me
A mother's love for her son
Unspoken, and maybe
Yeah, I took your love for granted
And all the things you said to me
I need your arms to welcome me
But, a cold stone's all I see
---------------------------------------

On the road he heard of his mother's passing. He is coming home for to bury her... He explains that she was disappointed in him for his life choices, but he feels like she should have loved him anyways. He regrets the same thing many of us do when a family member dies. He figured she would be around forever. So he realizes that he took it for granted and he wished to reconcile their differences, but it was too late as he stood over her grave..


This might sound too literal, but I can relate. I moved away from my mother on terrible terms. I moved 2000 miles away and recently she died in a house fire. I went up to participate in the services and it was too late. I couldn't take anything back, and every day now... I wish I could have called her up and said I am sorry.

This song really resonates with me now that I understand his pain in a very similar manner.

Really eye opening song. Always squash your differences with a family member. Things happen, and it might be too late to take things back.
